website_summaries.verdict: It lacks fancy features, but for users who prefer a basic model, it has all the necessary functions.
pros: A basic quartz model that's easy to use
Has adjustable volume and lighted tempo indicator
cons: The dial is somewhat hard to read from a distance
On/off switch and battery door feel flimsy

customer_reviews.title: Nice and loud
customer_reviews.text: We got this metronome three months ago and have used it daily for two piano students—we are still on the first set of batteries. It has a nice loud sound that is audible over playing, and the blinking light is helpful also. A good product and I wish we had bought it ages ago!
customer_reviews.author: L

customer_reviews.title: Cannot adjust tempo in consistent increments
customer_reviews.text: The unit itself is well made and loud enough to hear over my practice amp however I did not realize that the tempo adjusts 2 - 8 beats at a time depending on where you are on the dial. That means it's not possible to increase the tempo in 1 beat/min increments or even 10 beat/min increments sometimes it's either +2, +4, +6, or +8. That's not a huge deal but it's annoying that I can't start at 50 and raise the tempo an even 10 beats at a time when practicing speed and accuracy, it goes 50, 60, 72, 80, 92, 100. Easy to use and the dial makes for fast adjustments though, I'm keeping it.
customer_reviews.author: Juice Box

customer_reviews.title: Simple no-nonsense metronome
customer_reviews.text: I play classical/flamenco guitar and just want a simple metronome. The click sounds (you have two choices) are fine/non-grating and I like the fact that I can adjust the volume. (I always turn it down near the low end.) I considered a fancier metronome but decided that simpler is better. For example, some metronomes let you tap a beat to set the tempo but who cares when turning the dial to the desired tempo is just as easy.
customer_reviews.author: Liam C Murray

customer_reviews.title: An excellent update
customer_reviews.text: This is essentially the same as the SQ50 which it replaced (I believe) with the main difference being the addition of a volume control so that either sound can be adjusted from pretty loud to off, and anywhere in between. There is no switch setting for "silent mode", just either tones. The red LED is always on but the unit can easily be placed face down or taped if it's a bother. I have no issue with the LED, and the two different tones are very useful. Very handy and attractive metronome.
customer_reviews.author: Flashback

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent Tempo
customer_reviews.text: This metronome fails to keep a consistent tempo. At first I thought maybe it was having a problem due to an old battery, or something, but I've tried multiple new batteries and the problem continues to occur. It goes along fine for a while, but every once in a while it throws in an off-tempo click. Very annoying. I'm quite disappointed, as I like the dial, I like the simplicity, and I think the click sounds fine. But if it can't keep consistent time, then it's of no use at all. That's it's entire purpose, and it simply doesn't do it.
customer_reviews.author: J. Cone

customer_reviews.title: Perfect Pulser
customer_reviews.text: This is my second Seiko metronome. My other one is quite old so I needed a replacement. I prefer this metronome to the free ones on my cellphone because there are more time settings available plus you get two tuning tones A440 for C instruments and Bb for brass. You can also use microphones or just look at the light pulse the beat. There is a low and high tone to choose from as well as a dial to increase or decrease the volume of the beat.
customer_reviews.author: A.A. Riley:) Author of the Key of Aramath

customer_reviews.title: BIG SCAM!!! Don't buy this product!
customer_reviews.text: We have an old metronome but my son's teacher wanted a smaller portable one to bring to class and to show him how to properly use it. Other than the one time we opened the package to see if the product works when we received it, today is the second time ever that we used the metronome. And, lo and behold, the switch fell out the moment the teacher tried to turn on the metronome. Is this a joke or is this a joke??? This is a one-time use metronome?? And it costs $24++??? Someone explain to me how is this not a scam.
customer_reviews.author: SL

customer_reviews.title: This just arrived yesterday and I'm already glad I bought it
customer_reviews.text: This just arrived yesterday and I'm already glad I bought it. The Korg digital unit I was using was a bit quiet for me but this gets loud enough to not disappear. The two tones it produces is a nice touch allowing me to get a string in tune then use adjacent string tuning by ear using harmonics or whatever other method you prefer. The only thing a digital model does that this won't is dividing the beats for 8ths, 16ths, etc. Not a big deal for me.
customer_reviews.author: cj

customer_reviews.title: Lasted three months...then went berserk
customer_reviews.text: It was fine at first (although it doesn't get quite as loud as I'd like for kids getting used to tempo over the sound of a piano). But after three months of VERY LITTLE USE, it would start going into fits where it did double and triple beats for no reason. I've cycled power, and it does it on both the high and low pitch. It seems to do it more on high volumes, but it's doing it at all settings. Basically, it's useless now.
customer_reviews.author: infernalcolonel

customer_reviews.title: Perfect Metronome
customer_reviews.text: This is a great metronome. Exactly the features I need. Two tuning pitches, volume control, two tones two choose from for the sound of the “tock”, earphone port, incorporated stand and attractive black shiny finish. Compact. Very simple and effective. A light also marks the beat for silent operation. (If light is a problem, turn metronome away from you,) Everything you need and nothing you don’t need. A solid, well made, precision instrument. Lovely.
customer_reviews.author: fulene

customer_reviews.title: Classic Tool that is Suited to the Task
customer_reviews.text: This classic design (has it changed in decades??) simply does the job that needs to be done with a simply, direct interface. Sure, zillions of smartphone apps do this (and much more fancy stuff that you NEVER actually use...) for free or near-free, but you don't get the speed and easy of control and (most importantly) the sound quality and volume that carries through even loud music, no matter the instrument(s). It is a pleasure to use. Wish I'd bought one years ago.
customer_reviews.author: D. N. Knisely

customer_reviews.title: A retro electronic metronome. How cool! However, there are a couple of problems.
customer_reviews.text: As one online reviewer said, this metronome won't make you want to kill yourself. That's because it has an old-fashion dial tempo control rather than a digital one. Its sound is also retro: you get two choices, both traditional woodblock sounds, both very pleasant. However, there is a small problem: The power switch and volume control are recessed and tricky to find with one hand. When you turn the unit on with the thumb of your right hand, you might accidentally turn down the volume with your index finger, causing you to think that the device is malfunctioning or that the battery is dead.
customer_reviews.author: Dan S

customer_reviews.title: Earphone NOT included
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the metronome with the intent to regulate my strumming by listening to the beat with a headphone while actually playing a song. I was disappointed to learn it is not included and Amazon can not produce one. I am not interested in a stereo earphone. I realize it is my own fault but a disclaimer that the earphone was Not INCLUDED would have been helpful. I'll have to search elsewhere...
customer_reviews.author: Jimothy

customer_reviews.title: Failed in two months
customer_reviews.text: After two months not heavy use, the sound ceased to work. Flash only. I changed battery, no help. I took it apart to see if any other soldered points on components were cracked, but the sound unit is under the circuit board, which has no screws so no help there; I can resolder but not if I have to potentially break something to get to it. Money out the window. My 80's era old one, BTW, is going strong and actually does more. Not recommended.
customer_reviews.author: Joanna D.

customer_reviews.title: You get what you paid for
customer_reviews.text: My daughter started to get her violin lesson so I wanted her to have a metronome to understand tempo. I thought a warehouse deal couldn't be bad because a metronome is just a simple tool. The amazon.com proudly put the sticker in the box and notified that the machine was inspected. Unfortunately, the nob in the side was missing and you cannot even turn the machine on. So here is my question to Amazon.com. How were you able to check the machine works while you cannot even turn the machine on? It is really disappointing. I will send it back.
customer_reviews.author: goodreader

customer_reviews.title: Very Good Metronome
customer_reviews.text: This metronome has the indispensable (for me) volume control that my older model Seiko lacked. The only downside to the newer model is the indicator arrow showing the speed setting. It is a raised portion of the clear plastic rotating front with no line on it. It's impossible to see the indicator in anything but bright light, so I drew a line on it with a black Sharpie. Problem solved. Makes me wonder what the designers were thinking. "Oh, let's improve the model by making the arrow nearly invisible." Sheesh! Edit 9/11/15: Someone pointed out in another review that the lettering on the wheel lines up with the arrow. True, but why bother having an invisible arrow?
customer_reviews.author: Wray Mould

customer_reviews.title: Loud volume breaks the speed
customer_reviews.text: We liked it at first, but after a few months we noticed the speed was ALWAYS fast no matter the setting on the dial. After playing with it a lot we learned that as long as the volume is turned way down the speed is fine. But if you turn up the volume on it loud enough to hear while you play, it immediately defaults to the fastest speed. If it worked we'd love it. But no such luck. Mechanical metronome for us next.
customer_reviews.author: Amy Egbert

customer_reviews.title: Like it because of its simplicity
customer_reviews.text: I've got a second one of these. The switch on the first one broke, probably because my kid dropped it. I was expecting such a simple design to be sturdier. It turns out the little switch was impossible to fix without replacing it. Everything else worked without problems. Looking for a replacement, I came back to Seiko because I like the simple design and was willing to give it another try. You can get a metronome app with all the functions you can imagine these days, most time for free. To me, the only reason for getting a real metronome is simplicity and less distraction to kids.
customer_reviews.author: Amzuser

customer_reviews.title: Quartz Metronome
customer_reviews.text: This thing keeps better time than I do!! I use this during my drum lessons as a "click track" when practicing rudiments with my drum students. I've used the metronomes with the swinging arm for years, this little gadget has them all beat!!
customer_reviews.author: Tony A.

customer_reviews.title: Simple.
customer_reviews.text: I am all about simple. With a quick twist, we are clicking away at tempo. This is the model I have used all my musician life--30 years? An out of town student accidentally took mine, so I needed to replace it. Digital metronomes just about make me go mental. Free is nice (apps), but when I am working with my flute students, it takes time to open my phone, pull up the app, set it to the right tempo, etc. Occasionally it is nice to have more options that come with an app, but I can get those for free and deal with my phone when I find that necessary. This is my go-to device. Love. it.
customer_reviews.author: SJF

customer_reviews.title: Perfect, easy functioning metronome
customer_reviews.text: I bought this as a gift for my husband who teaches guitar. He loves it. He said it’s so much easier and faster when teaching to just turn the dial and get it started versus the digital one he had which required selections, buttons etc. The only difference between this analog and the digital besides dial vs selection screen is there’s no selecting a beat to be accentuated as in 3/4 time etc. Digital did have that. I told him his gadgets can’t teach his class for him.
customer_reviews.author: Gypsy Lane

customer_reviews.title: This would be a great, simple
customer_reviews.text: This would be a great, simple, nice sounding metronome, but after just a couple of days the beat wasn't consistent and would stay at about 60 bps no matter what setting I had it on. I sent it back for a full refund.
customer_reviews.author: Tikki

customer_reviews.title: Not Durable-Switch doesn't last
customer_reviews.text: This metronome worked fine at first, but it isn't very durable. The On/Off toggle switch on the side is made of thin plastic and in my case broke after limited use. I was not hard on the product at all. It sat atop a piano and was only used on occasion. Maybe mine was a manufacturing defect, but either way, the On/Off toggle switch base is made of thin plastic and the one on mine broke after limited and light use so it no longer works.
customer_reviews.author: Mandl

customer_reviews.title: Loud enough for use with piano
customer_reviews.text: Well priced, louder than most (a plus), uses a dial to adjust to desired speed (40-208 beats/min.; 39 steps), has 2 different sounds (one higher, one lower tone, both sound like a digital wooden cluck, ok sounding, not terrible), also has a blinking red light for an added visual speed cue, volume control, earphone jack, is portable (uses one 9-volt battery), and has a built-in easel stand. A metronome with a tempo dial was preferred by my son's piano teacher. Perfect fit for us! Would be even better if there was the option of using an AC adapter too. Still, this is the 3rd digital metronome we've purchased (2 kids) & has the best features for sure!
customer_reviews.author: Elizabeth Meei

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use and music teachers recommend them
customer_reviews.text: My kids are both musicians and they love this metronome. We live in Texas and marching band is the thing here. I put one of these in each child’s Easter basket around Easter time and they loved it. The only disadvantage to this metronome is that the other kids in the band like it and always want to borrow it.
customer_reviews.author: Patti

customer_reviews.title: It Doesn't Get Any Easier than This
customer_reviews.text: Easy, simple, no fuss, no unneeded features. It has a single switch that controls on/off and the beeping sound. A big, clearly marked dial on the front easily sets the speed, either by beats per minute or in musical terms, that is, Largo, Andante, Presto, etc. A simple dial controls the volume. It's so easy you don't even have to read the instructions. There's even a headphone jack for whenever it's necessary to be quiet. I was very unhappy with my previous metronome. It had too many features I never used, and the interface was a bit complicated and unintuitive. My new Seiko is just what I needed. I highly recommend it.
customer_reviews.author: Bododio

customer_reviews.title: Simple to use
customer_reviews.text: Terrific little metronome. Works wonders in helping my boy's timing on his violin. Way easier to use than a phone app or keyboard metronome. Just sits on his music stand or dresser and clicks away. Has everything you need. Simple and easy to use, very glad I bought it. I purchased the hard case for him to store it in as well.
customer_reviews.author: B L

customer_reviews.title: Ticks and takes a fall
customer_reviews.text: Fidgety six-year-olds do not stay still. No matter where you keep this, it will be touched, prodded, sped up, slowed down, and kept back haphazardly resulting in a drop. Metronome took said drop like a champ and for that, this is a great purchase. Two frequencies and a volume control (apparently said six-year-olds cannot hear the ticking unless it is above the volume of them playing lion paw on the upright) are definitely useful.
customer_reviews.author: Ravi N.

customer_reviews.title: Nice metronome. Small type.
customer_reviews.text: This is what I was looking for. It seems like metronomes these days are over-complicated digital devices. I wanted something simple to use that keeps time for my piano practice. This does the job. One star off only because the type size of the BPMs is very small.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew S.

customer_reviews.title: This thing keeps time for the times I want to keep time
customer_reviews.text: Not perfect, but it is a nice simple metronome. I've been working between fancy tablet/phone things and an old mechanical not so very steady one. This has been a vast improvement. No need to find an app. It just waits for me every day, turn me on, how many bps, how loud. I want to play in 7/8? fine, but I will just click eighths. I like the simplicity. Music is hard enough.
customer_reviews.author: H. Sweet

customer_reviews.title: Good portable unit
customer_reviews.text: I got an accurate one. I like the block sound on this metronome. Flashing red light is eye catching but not overly obtrusive. I haven’t found a metronome app with sounds and flashing lights or gimmicks that don’t annoy me. I’m sticking with this simple unit that’s small enough to throw in a gig bag or place on a music stand.
customer_reviews.author: Ashe

customer_reviews.title: A first-rate metronome
customer_reviews.text: I've been using this metronome for several years, and it works perfectly. Settings for high and low pitch clicks plus a volume control (and a blinking LED light in case you prefer to follow a visual tempo). What else could you ask for?
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good!
customer_reviews.text: This replaces my old metronome same brand. They've added a volume control and it is easier to read than the old one, though that could still be improved. Also plays a 440 A if needed. Nice loud volume.
customer_reviews.author: Susan

customer_reviews.title: This was perfect. Variable volume and the light is bright enough ...
customer_reviews.text: Playing in a church band with a learning teenage drummer we need some help. This was perfect. Variable volume and the light is bright enough to be seen from across the room by the whole band. Excellent product.
customer_reviews.author: J. Mitchell

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy, long-lasting, portable.  Great for musicians of all levels
customer_reviews.text: We bought this metronome after reading the many reviews and the positive reviewers did not lie. This is a sturdy, long-lasting, portable, steady gadget perfect for the budding musician. Our kids' piano teacher approved it right away and even asked where we bought it. The volume is loud and clear and makes it easy for little musicians to keep tempo. I like its compact design, which means we can easily stow it away or pack it if the kids need to practice at their grandparents' house. As for battery power, I can tell you that we haven't changed the battery in months.
customer_reviews.author: two kids and a dog

customer_reviews.title: The ideal compact metronome
customer_reviews.text: This metronome feels like old-school Japanese electronics. Heavy for the size and solid. The audible tick is nice and loud and sounds like a metronome should. The tuning tones work fine, though we don’t use that feature too much. It’s easy to adjust the tempo and that’s it for controls. Perfect.
customer_reviews.author: T. Briggs

customer_reviews.title: Seiko Metronome
customer_reviews.text: This metronome has selective volume control and two pitches. It is the fourth metronome I've had in 80 years. I love it! It is small and easy to pack, it's sturdy, and doesn't have a lot of "bell" and "whistles". It is perfect for classical music. Very reasonable price.
customer_reviews.author: Susan R

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Metronome with a variety of features
customer_reviews.text: I use this with my piano practice and love it. It's tough, easy to use and has a variety of settings for speed and the sound of the ticks. It has an earphone jack, volume control, etc. It looks great on my piano.
customer_reviews.author: Dan Proctor

customer_reviews.title: Pleasant sound with volume control
customer_reviews.text: This is the most pleasant sounding electronic metronome I've heard to date. There are two tones to choose from, and both have enough punch to be heard even at lower volumes. I really like the volume control as well. My last electronic Metronome was *very* *loud* and difficult on my hearing-aids in a small studio. It's so nice to be able to turn the volume down to a reasonable level. The finish is nice too, and it couldn't be easier to operate. I would definitely get this again.
customer_reviews.author: P. Riddell

customer_reviews.title: Must have for piano lessons
customer_reviews.text: Bought these based on piano teacher recommendation to help with rhythm , so glad I did. My boys are taking piano lessons , they play the notes correctly but they’re off on rhythm, this tool helps with the number of beats. You can easily adjust the rate of speed as needed.
customer_reviews.author: AnaHill

customer_reviews.title: Broken after 4 months of light using
customer_reviews.text: It stoped working after 4 months of using. Just stop to respond to any controls. Replacing battery does not help. Very poor quality. Unexpected to see Such a poor quality product from Seiko
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: It's Okay, but the old wooden ones are the best
customer_reviews.text: Good metronome. Keeps accurate time and easy to use. To understand how to use the dial, you have to understand what the tempos like Allegro, Andante, etc. mean. The numbers around the dial are beats and can usually be found in the upper left corner of your music sheet (ex quarter note = 120). I still wish I had my old, manual, wind-up one. The beat "knocks" emitted from this are rather harsh, but closer to the manual one than any other that I've heard. The beeps are obnoxious, so I don't use them. So, for the money, it's a keeper.
customer_reviews.author: Joanne R. Ackerman

customer_reviews.title: Just shy of perfect. :)
customer_reviews.text: Got this for doing CPR. Nice and loud, cuts past all the noise and confusion. The flashing light is a bonus. My only issue is the metronome rate is separated into divisible by 4. So I can either do 108 or 112 bpm when I really need 110. Not enough to lose a star over, just good to know about it.
customer_reviews.author: B. Wilson

customer_reviews.title: Small and simple...
customer_reviews.text: Metronome for piano practice. Simple to use, two beat tones, earphone jack, good selection of speeds, volume control, blinking light with beat audio. 9volt battery, small easel to stand upright or lay flat. Sturdy plastic condtruction, I am very happy with this purchase. A very simple audio beat to make restarts during say scales easy.
customer_reviews.author: Edward W Hutton Jr

customer_reviews.title: Great Metronome
customer_reviews.text: This instantly became my new favorite metronome. After all these months, it is still my favorite - of all four I have this is the only one I use any more.
customer_reviews.author: Robert

customer_reviews.title: Good metronome
customer_reviews.text: The tuners I have for my guitar/banjo have modes for use as a metronome. The problem is to use them as a metronome you have to push a small multifunction button to switch to metronome function, then press smaller buttons to set the speed of the metronome. I find them annoying. This metronome can be set with one hand by simply turning it on and twisting a dial. The speed is easy to read and setting the loudness of the metronome clicks is easily changed. And there are two clicks to choose from. The metronome has a flashing light too. Overall a very useable metronome. 5 stars.
customer_reviews.author: J. Walker

customer_reviews.title: This would have been a (5) star, as the ...
customer_reviews.text: This would have been a (5) star, as the sound quality and the multiple tones are awasome but I can't seem to get the headset to work properly on both ears even after buying 3 different headsets. I'm too lazy to return them so I will just keep it and deal with it.
customer_reviews.author: Chase5326

customer_reviews.title: Good metronome
customer_reviews.text: I like how this has a volume control. My other metronome didn't have that and it would be pretty loud at night. I also like the 2 metronome sounds you could get. One is very pleasant and the other I don't like as much. But, I imagine the latter cuts through the texture when you can't hear it over your playing.
customer_reviews.author: Brian F

customer_reviews.title: Sounds different through headphones
customer_reviews.text: Very easy to use and the sound is fine using the built in speaker. However through headphones the sound becomes a painful thump instead of a click or tap
customer_reviews.author: Harold Zweng

customer_reviews.title: Handy and versatile
customer_reviews.text: This is a battery-operated metronome with all the features that I could want. It's easy to turn on and off, and the volume and type of the click can be adjusted. If you don't want the sound, you can have just a red light flashing. The dials are easy to read. It is compact and can either stand up or lie down.
customer_reviews.author: D. Timbers

customer_reviews.title: WAY TOO FAST
customer_reviews.text: When I first got this, it was fine. A few months later the beat goes way too fast no matter what speed is chosen. 40 BPM is about 200 BPM. Don't get this one, buy one made by a different company.
customer_reviews.author: Boo

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use
customer_reviews.text: Easy to use, volume adjustable from off to quite loud. Very long battery life. Unless you need a metronome that can handle different time signatures or need a particular beat accented this will do the trick.
customer_reviews.author: Dave V

customer_reviews.title: It beats doubly fast with some 9v batteries.
customer_reviews.text: It works however I put an energizer battery in and regardless of where its set such as andante, it is double time. I finally found a generic 9v and now it works again.
customer_reviews.author: AC

customer_reviews.title: Broke in 3 months. Calls to Seiko get a runaround: no one knows who to call for warranty/repairs
customer_reviews.text: The slider on the right fell off about 3 months after we bought it. Seiko does not appear to have a customer support or warranty number to call. I called various Seiko numbers and they sent me to various other numbers and finally to KMC, who said they do not repair them and could not give me a repair contact.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: The best metronome!
customer_reviews.text: My daughter's piano teacher uses it and I bought it for her. It's loud enough that you can hear it even when she plays forte. It's simple to change speed and you can change the tones (high and low). I hope the battery lasts long.
customer_reviews.author: M. BARE

customer_reviews.title: Defective-two times
customer_reviews.text: Both metronomes defective (purchased 2), it goes nuts if you turn up the volume. Disappointed!
customer_reviews.author: Stuart Stuart

customer_reviews.title: Loud and steady, solidly built.
customer_reviews.text: Loud! But has a great volume control to get real quiet. Bright flash, easy to see in moderate lighting. It would not be easy to see in sunlight or bright stage/spot lighting. Two different click sounds are nice. It also produces a tone for tuning. Read the details to find out more. Has a 3.5 head phone jack (see below) Of note: I use it for a drum student and it is not quite loud enough out in the open air - unless we play quietly, but seriously, what the hell metronome would be loud enough for that? That's where the headphone jack is great. :)
customer_reviews.author: AmazonTom

customer_reviews.title: seems fine. Those who
customer_reviews.text: Just received, so have no comments on durability, but as to the rest, seems fine. Those who, like me, prefer an analog interface to a digital one will like the dial that you rotate instead of inputting digits to get a particular speed. It has a volume control (top volume is ample and not softer than a traditional mechanical metronome) and an earplug socket. It has two sound options, one of which is the traditional tick-tock. What else does one need in a metronome?
customer_reviews.author: Daffy

customer_reviews.title: Lasts 15 years.
customer_reviews.text: I just bought an identical replacement after the "on" button fell off after 15 years of use. I like this model's "wood" sound, the light that also keeps the beat, the convenient size, its smooth feel in my hand, the loudness control, the headphone port and the numbers legibility. Each 9 volt battery lasts about 1.5 years.
customer_reviews.author: Marsha Drebelbis

customer_reviews.title: Quality issues
customer_reviews.text: This seems to be a good metronome. Good features include the dial to select conveniently the desired beat. However, there also seem to be some major quality issues - the first one I bought failed soon after purchase due to the on-off switch breaking off completely making it completely unusable. Thus, this seems not to be a top quality product.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Not too many of these left
customer_reviews.text: As always, for a piano player, the metronome could be louder. But other than that, this is easy to use and helpful. Helps to keep time while playing (if you can hear it).
customer_reviews.author: zacisbac

customer_reviews.title: This is a very good metronome, however the on off switch broke in about four months. Disappointed in the fact that the switch br
customer_reviews.text: This is a very good metronome, however the on off switch broke in about four months. Disappointed in the fact that the switch broke because the sound of this metronome works perfectly. We have to remove the battery and put it in to turn it on and off.
customer_reviews.author: Ronnie R

customer_reviews.title: Keeps Me On Beat
customer_reviews.text: I like this metronome because it has plenty of volume. Several of us can playing and still hear that steady beat. A few musician friends have said "I've noticed your ability to stay on tempo has approved." This neat device has disciplined me to patiently keep a beat. I can't say much more than this is a very helpful tool to improve my guitar and mandolin playing.
customer_reviews.author: Edward Shirley

customer_reviews.title: Seiko SQ50-V is a Great Quartz Metronome for the price
customer_reviews.text: Easy to use easy to read dial, two sounds, volume control, and has a stand to stand it upright. A well thought out design.
customer_reviews.author: JD-BuyItRight

customer_reviews.title: Poor quality or bad luck
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this item in May 2018 and after one month it stopped working. I contacted Amazon.com and an replacement was sent. After two months it stopped working again. Either the metronome has a poor quality or I am extremely unlucky.
customer_reviews.author: LOVENYC

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed!
customer_reviews.text: Thought Seiko would be reliable and good quality so I bought this. Had a good experience for the first year or so and then the metronome just went into 132, no matter if we are on 60 or 164. Now I have to buy a new one and throw this one away. Sad to see one more thing added to the landfill for no good reason. :(
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: completely adequate
customer_reviews.text: I got this metronome for assistance learning to walk once again after a leg operation. It seems to help. It seems adequate. It is loud enough to hear. The only unpleasant surprise is how relatively heavy it is. At about the size of a pack of cigarettes (remember those?), it is twice that weight. Quite acceptable, however.
customer_reviews.author: New Mexican

customer_reviews.title: Simple and exactly what is needed to keep time
customer_reviews.text: This is a handy good size metronome that is easy to take on the road so you can keep time where every you are! So reliable.
customer_reviews.author: Glenn

customer_reviews.title: Well Made, Practical
customer_reviews.text: Love these metronomes. I use them in my studio and find they work well as a basic metronome for students. Also, incredibly durable and one battery lasts for hours upon hours of practice!
customer_reviews.author: Rachel Elizabeth Sarrano

customer_reviews.title: My First Metronome
customer_reviews.text: My First Metronome. Works great for my guitar practice. Adjustable volume. Beats can be easily heard above my acoustic and above my electric when plugged into the practice amp. There is also a headset jack.
customer_reviews.author: Cameron Scholtz, PhD, RD

customer_reviews.title: Does the job
customer_reviews.text: This is for my son for his piano lessons. Not really much to say, but that it does the job for what I need.
customer_reviews.author: Anthony Tran

customer_reviews.title: great product!
customer_reviews.text: I like many features of this metronome! High quality and great price. Will last a lifetime.
customer_reviews.author: amanda vega

customer_reviews.title: Simple effective met
customer_reviews.text: If you need something simple, this is perfect. It was just what I wanted. If you need something other than quarter note clicks, or want clicks on different beats, etc, this isn't for you
customer_reviews.author: Griffin Johnston

customer_reviews.title: This is the best one available
customer_reviews.text: This, in my opinion, is the best metronome available on the market today. The reason is because most metronomes use beeps to indicate tempo, and if you play electric guitar, you can't hear the beep, even at moderate volumes. This metronome produces a very loud "click", not beep. There are two tones of the click (high and low), and volume is adjustable. It's very easy to operate - you set the tempo by turning the wheel. Granted, it doesn't have all those fancy rhythms in it, but at least you can hear it, while playing, which is the most important feature of them all, IMO.
customer_reviews.author: Some Dude

customer_reviews.title: Very cute and working well
customer_reviews.text: Very easy to use and loud enough when used with piano. It works very well as described.
customer_reviews.author: xiaotuma

customer_reviews.title: Awesome!
customer_reviews.text: I got this for my 9 years old because she is learning to read music and this is amazing. Her violin teacher recommended it and its truly awesome.
customer_reviews.author: Clarice Mariz Sagebin

customer_reviews.title: Works Great
customer_reviews.text: Needed this to record a piece on the clarinet. It has different settings to play in A or Bb. The volume is adjustable and it gets loud enough to hear while playing. I would recommend this
customer_reviews.author: L. Milo

customer_reviews.title: Simple
customer_reviews.text: When I sit down to practice my guitar, I just want something very simple to keep time. It was a pain previously to have to mess with menus and such on a computer to bring up a metronome app from tablet, phone or computer. With this, I'll just have to flip a switch and dial the tempo that I want. Simple and loud enough for me to practice my guitar routines. I do recommend this one.
customer_reviews.author: Minh Pham

customer_reviews.title: Excellent volume and accuracy
customer_reviews.text: This is the best metronome I have ever used. The volume control and accuracy are what makes this a great metronome.
customer_reviews.author: Martin A Empringham

customer_reviews.title: Short shelf life
customer_reviews.text: Bought it on Sep. 2018 Now it’s not working🤦🏻‍♀️ The beat goes way too fast no matter what speed we choose.
customer_reviews.author: Hanyan Jacinto

customer_reviews.title: Simple and sturdy but limited
customer_reviews.text: This is a sturdy and easy to use metronome. My only complaints are that (1) the speed increments by 3 beats and (2) the same tone clicks each time. I would like to set my bpm to any value, incrementing by 1. I also get confused by the same tone each beat and wish you could alternate mild and heavy tones for the up and down beats. While I use this, almost any smartphone metronome app has many more features. I just don't like running down my phone's battery.
customer_reviews.author: Eclectic Reader

customer_reviews.title: Compact metronome
customer_reviews.text: Wonderful size, can easily transport to lessons if need be. Sound is perfect, easy to hear but not too loud. Use it all the time for piano exercises and to set tempos. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Jeanne Marie

customer_reviews.title: Failed after 2 months.
customer_reviews.text: Failed after 2 months. The beats are much faster than before, basically out of sync somehow.
customer_reviews.author: Tempest

customer_reviews.title: Nice for kids!
customer_reviews.text: My kids are in piano lesson and this metronome is perfect for them. Loud enouph for them to be able to hear it when they are playing Forte. And not complicated at all to use. Five stars from us!
customer_reviews.author: PickyMomma

customer_reviews.title: Workhorse
customer_reviews.text: This thing is a brute. It sits outside on my front porch, year round, and has been dropped, stepped on and banged countless times. I have 7 and 2 yr old boys and they brutalize it and it still works great. Highly recommend
customer_reviews.author: J. Murdoch

customer_reviews.title: Bought used but still new
customer_reviews.text: It works well. High or low volume. Does what it's supposed to do...tick...tock....keeping my music timed....
customer_reviews.author: Linda Lou

customer_reviews.title: metronome
customer_reviews.text: This is a great metronome. The ticks can be easily heard over a piano. It has a low and a high pitch tick. The only downside is the numbers in the red area are very small. Kids can see them easily but if you don't have 20/20 vision you have to squint to read them. The dial turns to the right to get faster gradually and to the left to get gradually slower.I use it at my piano studio and recommend it to my students to use at home. A nine volt battery lasts a good while. It has a built in medal stand to keep it upright.
customer_reviews.author: E. Hughes

customer_reviews.title: Excellent product
customer_reviews.text: Had it for over a year now and still going strong even after being dropped several times!!
customer_reviews.author: C Dub

customer_reviews.title: Metronome
customer_reviews.text: I'm a speech pathologist and bought this to replace an old "wind-up" model. This is so much better, I use this working with my fluency students (stuttering) and once we've achieved a more fluid rate we can lower/fade the volume out, which was not an option on my old one. And it a great price, I'm sure I paid more 10 years ago for the wind up one!
customer_reviews.author: H. P. Stone

customer_reviews.title: The unit that arrived at my house did not work ...
customer_reviews.text: The unit that arrived at my house did not work properly. About a third of the way up the dial the tempo started DECREASING. I have no idea why that would happen.
customer_reviews.author: PHD76

customer_reviews.title: Good product
customer_reviews.text: Excellent product You can hear it perfectly while playing the piano
customer_reviews.author: JR

customer_reviews.title: learning tool
customer_reviews.text: My adult daughter is learning piano. the metronome is a little bit of help I got her for her birthday. she loves it and it is so compact and small it fits on her keyboard.
customer_reviews.author: MARISKE

customer_reviews.title: works great
customer_reviews.text: Loud enough, reliable. We switched form an old analogue to this. Great quality/price ratio.
customer_reviews.author: busy mom

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: This was a gift for a vocalist. Two different tones, up to 200 bpm, and lists the coinciding musical terms for the bpm which helps her to better understand the terms. She's happy with it!
customer_reviews.author: Kondronie

customer_reviews.title: It worked great until it didn't
customer_reviews.text: I must have received a dud because it stopped working after 3 practice sessions. I tried replacing the batteries and all that stuff but nothing helped.
customer_reviews.author: JS

customer_reviews.title: Exactly what it should be
customer_reviews.text: Does exactly what a metronome should. I wish it was a bit louder, but I can always route it through a speaker or headphones.
customer_reviews.author: Atticus Taintwater

customer_reviews.title: durable
customer_reviews.text: work well, my kids keep drop it but still working
customer_reviews.author: THANH VU

customer_reviews.title: Not fully functional
customer_reviews.text: The unit I received functions as advertised except for the dual tone function. The On/Off switch has three positions but moving it between the 2nd and 3rd positions has no effect. The volume control works fine. That was sufficient for my use so I didn’t bother returning it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Awesome metronome
customer_reviews.text: I love this metronome. It's super loud which helps my kids stay in time. It's easy to adjust. It's easy to see the numbers. It has a headphone attachment. It stands up nicely. And best of all... it keeps really good time! I've had lots of metronomes throughout the years (used to be a professional guitarist) and this one is the best one yet.
customer_reviews.author: W. Ullrich

customer_reviews.title: Good!
customer_reviews.text: This seems to be we'll made and work well. Doesn't have as many features as others but good value for your money
customer_reviews.author: sheri spencer

product_meta.title: Seiko SQ50-V Quartz Metronome
product_meta.description: The sq50-v Quartz metronome is an upgrade from Seiko sq50 and features new look, Easy operation tempo dial, adjustable volume, two selectable click tones (high and low), and two tone generators (a and Bb). dial-in virtually perfect tempo settings and an a=440 tone for tuning. Tempo range from 40-208bpm can be set easily from the two-position rotary dial. A red LED can be selected for a visual beat or combined with a click sound for visual and audible beat-keeping. Includes earphone jack.
feature_bullets: Choose from 2 types of sounds for tempo and beat
Red LED light on the top gives a clear visual tempo indication that is great for practicing without click or during performance
Reference tuning tones for a (440) and Bb (446. 1)
Tempo range from 40-208bpm can be set easily from the 39-position rotary dial

specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.5 out of 5 stars1,452 ratings4.5 out of 5 stars
